projects.title: TKI urban energy : BlueBattery and hydrogen car as sustainable and local electricity storage in microgrids
projects.description:
Background
The use of solar panels in the built environment is on the rise. Due to the fluctuating supply of solar energy, and because the use of new electrical technologies (e.g. electric driving, induction cooking and heat pumps) will result in extra-large consumption on the low-voltage grid in the coming decade, the distribution and timing of electricity supply will be a major challenge. Local storage of electricity can play a major role in this.

A consortium led by AquaBattery recently built a pilot installation of the Blue Battery at The Green Village in Delft, which stores sustainable electricity in fresh and salt water. This project was funded by a TKI Urban Energy subsidy project (TEUE116250), contributions from grid operators (Alliander and Enexis) and own financing. This battery has been used successfully and is now connected to the electricity grid. In addition, TU Delft has tested at the same location with a hydrogen car that can function as an electricity source (Car as a Power plant). Both techniques have the potential to balance electricity consumption and generation locally.

Objective
Mix of consumers and producers makes it important to think about when something is switched on or off. For example, with extra electricity consumption, both the Blue Battery and the Hydrogen car can supply energy. With the growing number of different users of The Green Village, there is an excellent basis to analyze the modern consumption and generation patterns and to test the practical use of energy balancing. It will be investigated whether the advantages of microgrids (less investment in thick cabling, simple & smart energy management) outweighs the use of additional energy balancing in the form of a Blue Battery and Hydrogen car. The ultimate goal of this project is to create an efficient integration, implementation and validation of different local electricity sources, consumers and storage methods.

contributors.headline: Reliability Lead & Equipment Strategy Facilitator I Ex-President/Chairman YES-DC I Ex-Governance Board Member EYEN I  I Volunteer IFMLM I Scientific Researcher I Electrochemistry I Leadership in Energy Transition I

projects.title: European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme : BAoBaB: Blue Acid/Base Battery
projects.description:
Our aim is to research and develop a totally new, environment-friendly, cost-competitive, grid-scale Electrical Energy Storage (EES) system, and apply this system in the existing electricity grid. This technology, referred to as “Blue Acid/Base Battery” (BAoBaB), stores electrical energy using pH and salinity differences in water. The principle of BAoBaB is altering the acid-base balance by means an excess of available electricity to obtain an acid and base from its corresponding salt. When electricity is needed, acid and base are recombined into their corresponding salt again while obtaining electrical work from the entropy and enthalpy gain. The energy density stored in such osmotic and pH-gradients outcompetes, by an order of magnitude, pumped hydropower, which is currently the leading technology for large scale electrical energy storage. In combination with the wide applicability (no geographical limitations) and scalability (operational in a range of kW-kWh up to MW-MWh), this innovative technology is attractive for stationary electrical energy storage. It is safer and more sustainable than other battery technologies as it does neither contain toxic chemicals nor scarce elements.
Our goal is to develop this next generation storage technology from ‘proof of concept’ (TRL3) to ‘validated in relevant environment’ (TRL5).

projects.title: Use of bioflocculants in wastewater: anionic flocculants overview and bio-based flocculants performance from sludge from three different wastewater treatment plants in the Nethelands.
projects.description:
Several chemicals are used in drinking water production and wastewater treatment plants.
Inorganic and organic compounds are employed in flocculation and dewatering processes to
separate solids from the water. After these treatments, certain substances remain in solids
and the solution. Some of them, based on aluminum salts and polyacrylamide monomer, are
harmful to the ecosystem. Consequently, the industry is investigating compounds with higher
biocompatibility that performance similar to the conventional chemicals. This project  presents
a general overview of cationic and anionic flocculants employed in the industry and their
performance in wastewater samples of Amsterdam , Leeuwarden and Dronten in the Netherlands

projects.title: TKI Urban Energy :  Development and integration of Blue Battery for electrical energy storage within built environment
projects.description:
Background
Development and integration of the Blue Battery for electrical energy storage within a built environment: Blue Battery System (BBS)

We are developing an energy storage system with an integrated battery management system that uses the Blue Energy technology, and will thus contribute to the ambition to develop an innovative product in the field of flexibility and efficiency of renewable energy sources. This system is called the Blue Battery System (BBS).

Objective To
develop and scale up BBS from a lab product to a practical and scalable solution for energy storage and power supply at times when there is little sun or wind, and to test how this works within an operational scale by means of a pilot with 1 kW power and 10 kWh capacity.

company.name: Maria Luisa de Moreno International Foundation

profile_positions.company: Maria Luisa de Moreno International Foundation
profile_positions.description:
Through the execution of human development programs, the María Luisa de Moreno International Foundation works for the benefit of vulnerable communities applying models of social intervention that seek the transformation of people, generally applying the method "Discover Capacity, an Opportunity" authored by Dr. Maria Luisa Piraquive.

By virtue of the foregoing, it develops its social work through three strategic lines focused on education, humanitarian aid, social welfare, entrepreneurship and productivity. Her work has been replicated with similar foundations and social organizations in countries such as Canada, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Spain, England, Mexico, Panama, Peru and Switzerland. Work has also been done in other countries such as Bolivia and from England and Switzerland, the Foundation managed important aid to benefit vulnerable communities in Bamenda (Cameroon) in Africa, as well as for the cities of Bangalore in India and Shanghai in China.
profile_positions.title: Education Volunteer - Sustainable energy & environment /  Introduction to project management.

profile_positions.description: The European Youth Energy Network (EYEN) is an emerging bottom-up, independent, inclusive, youth-led network of energy-focused youth organisations from across the European Union and beyond. In the framework of the European Climate Pact and of the Green New Deal, the EYEN aims to promote bilateral cooperation between (inter)governmental bodies and youth communities by co-creating youth dialogues and exchanging opportunities on a European, national, regional and local level.
profile_positions.title: Governance Board Member

profile_positions.description: The lack of formal European youth engagement mechanisms in different sectors is one of the biggest hurdles to advancing Europe’s ambitions, preventing direct youth participation in decision-making.  One excellent example is the European energy transition, marked by progressive goals to achieve climate neutrality by 2050, and invest significantly in renewable energy and energy efficiency. Here, youth have a key role to play in enhancing ambitions and catalysing action, by generating new ideas and meaningful discussions that will affect the speed and outlook of the transition
profile_positions.title: Project Management Advisor

profile_positions.description: Young Energy Specialists and Development Co-operation (YES-DC) is an association of students and young professionals interested and/or working in the field of energy and international co-operation. YES-DC started informally in October 1994, as a means to create a network and to facilitate the exchange of information and experiences. Since March 1996, YES-DC has officially been established as an association. YES-DC distinguishes itself by the diversity of its members; amongst us we have entrepreneurs, academic researchers and students, employees of energy and network companies, consultants and policy makers.
profile_positions.title: Chairman / President

company.name: Wetsus, European Centre of Excellence for Sustainable Water Technology

profile_positions.company: Wetsus, European Centre of Excellence for Sustainable Water Technology
profile_positions.description:
•	Research and development of near IR-light ( Laser) to identify and quantify inorganic salts in water by near-IR spectroscopy, in a concentration ranging from 0.03 to 0.5 M.
•	Modeling and simulation (Matlab) of the Mach-Zehnder interferometer to study the effect of the refractive index due to the absorbance of different components in water.
•	Compare measurements form the Mach-Zehnder interferometer done in the laser lab with the Matlab modeling.
•	Integration and implementation of the technology into a low-cost optical chip which enables direct and fast concentration measurement of relevant ions in drinking water.
•	Programming of Fringes formation, Signal filtering and fitting method to determine the refractive index (n) and the complex value (k) from free space Mach-Zehnder interferometer and optofluidic chips. For identify and quantify electrolytes in water.
